metadata.subject: Appellants' Consolidated Brief with Respect to Dismissals for Failure to State a Claim and Foreign Sovereign Immunity
metadata.sender: Ronald L. Motley, Robert T. Haefele, Motley Rice LLC; Stephen A. Cozen, Elliott R. Feldman, Sean P. Carter, Cozen O'Connor; Carter G. Phillips, Richard Klingler, Sidley Austin LLP; Andrea Bierstein, Hanly Conroy Bierstein Sheridan Fisher & Hayes, LLP; Robert M. Kaplan, Ferber Chan Essner & Coller, LLP; James P. Kreindler, Justin T. Green, Kreindler & Kreindler LLP; Jerry S. Goldman, Anderson Kill & Olick, P.C.; Chris Leonardo, Adams Holcomb LLP
recipients: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Alleged provision of banking services and financial support to Al Qaeda through charity fronts
Alleged major financier of Al Qaeda through various business entities and charitable donations
Alleged provision of financial vehicles for transferring millions to Islamic militants
Alleged central banking entity used to channel financial support to Al Qaeda
Alleged maintenance of accounts for Al Qaeda front charities and financing of projects

analysis.purpose: To reverse district court dismissals of claims against alleged financiers of Al Qaeda related to 9/11 attacks
analysis.significance: Major appellate brief in consolidated 9/11 litigation involving allegations of Saudi financial support for terrorism

notable_quotes: Plaintiffs allege that defendants knowingly provided extensive material support to al-Qaeda through a network of charities and financial institutions
The district court applied a heightened standard of scrutiny to plaintiffs' pleadings, one that has no basis in the Federal Rules
Money is fungible and funding for nonviolent activities frees up other resources within the organization that may be put to violent ends
red_flags: Allegations of systematic financial support to known terrorist organizations
Use of charitable organizations as fronts for terrorist financing
Pattern of ignoring banking regulations and warnings about terrorist financing

blackmail_indicators.description: No indications of blackmail or coercion found in this legal brief

evidence: Allegations of direct financial support to Al Qaeda
Use of banking systems for terrorist financing
Knowingly maintaining accounts for terrorist fronts
illegal_activity.description: Document contains allegations of illegal terrorism financing activities by various defendants, but these are legal claims being litigated rather than first-hand evidence of crimes

details: References to Wall Street Journal reports
Public reporting on terrorist activities of charities

public_knowledge.context: 9/11 litigation has been extensively covered in media; allegations of Saudi financing of terrorism have been public for years

analysis.summary: This appellate brief challenges district court dismissals of claims against alleged financiers of Al Qaeda, arguing that plaintiffs sufficiently pleaded that defendants knowingly provided material support to terrorism leading to the 9/11 attacks. The brief contends the district court applied incorrect legal standards and failed to properly credit extensive allegations of financial support through charity fronts and banking systems.
